messages.title: What will Green policies mean for Dulwich & West Norwood?
Greens will end Private Finance in the NHS
messages.content: The last Labour government extensively used PFI contracts for the NHS and schools, arguing (along with the Conservatives) that the private sector is better at delivering services than the public sector. The Coalition has continued this policy. Currently such contracts have in excess of £250 billion debt – debt which continues to be a burden for many hospitals and which led to the South London NHS Trust going bankrupt in 2012. Labour's manifesto says nothing about PFI, but Greens are committed to ending such back-door privatisation.

keyPolicies.policyDescription: Free insulation to high standard for 20,000 homes in the constituency by 2020, provide over 1000 new social rented homes at high standards, reduce VAT on housing renovation and repair to 5%, to encourage use and improvement of existing housing
Increase the minimum wage to £9.40 in London in 2015
Nationalisation of rail services and public investment to reduce fares, and end rail chaos and overcrowding
Means-testing of pensions and provide £180 weekly pension per person and free social care for the elderly
End the over-assessment of pupils, reduce class sizes to 20 and integrate free schools into the local authority system
End undergraduate tuition fees and restore public funding of universities
Bring in proportional representation for national and local elections, so that everyone's vote will count
Stop airport expansion, cut night flights, and reduce speed limits to 20mph across the constituency, enforce limits on air pollution, and end the incineration of waste

mentions.candidate: Rashid campaigning for Upper Norwood Library
mentions.otherPartyLeaderCandidate: The last Labour government, the Conservatives, The Coalition
mentions.tacticalSituation: 2014 local elections in D&WN: Green Party 16%, Cons 19%, LibDems 11.5% – a Green vote here will make a real difference and impact for the future.
